origin: Old English on, an, of Germanic origin; related to Dutch aan and German an, from an Indo-European root shared by Greek ana .

definitions.definition: physically in contact with and supported by (a surface).
definitions.example: on the table was a water jug

definitions.definition: forming a distinctive or marked part of the surface of.
having (the thing mentioned) as a topic; about.
as a member of (a committee, jury, or other body).
definitions.example: they would be allowed to serve on committees

definitions.definition: having (the thing mentioned) as a target, aim, or focus.
(often followed by a noun without a determiner) having (the thing mentioned) as a medium for transmitting or storing information.
definitions.example: put your ideas down on paper
he was on his way to see his mother

definitions.definition: indicating the day or part of a day during which an event takes place.

definitions.example: his attendant was out on errands
he is on morphine to relieve the pain
a few pence on the electricity bill is nothing compared with your security

definitions.definition: physically in contact with and supported by a surface.
definitions.example: make sure the lid is on

definitions.definition: indicating continuation of a movement or action.
(of an event) taking place or being presented.
definitions.example: what's on at the May Festival

definitions.definition: (of an electrical appliance or power supply) functioning.
definitions.example: they always left the lights on
